ResourceHeader.AlternateName: Dynamics Explorer 1 8 Second Orbit and Attitude Data
DE-A 8 Second Orbit and Attitude Data

RevisionEvent.Note: Only known prior ReleaseDate of the metadata
Added DOI and PublicationInfo minted by LFB, metadata versioned up to SPASE 2.6.0, reviewed by LFB 20230727

ResourceHeader.Description: Two Dynamics Explorer (DE) spacecraft were launched August 3, 1981, and placed into coplanar polar orbits with DE-1 in a highly elliptical orbit and DE-2 in a lower more circular orbit. The primary objective of the DE program was to investigate magnetosphere-ionosphere-atmosphere coupling processes. The DE mission provided a wealth of new information on a wide variety of magnetospheric plasma wave phenomena including auroral kilometric radiation, auroral hiss, Z mode radiation, narrow-band electromagnetic emissions associated with equatorial upper hybrid waves, whistler mode emissions, wave-particle interactions stimulated by ground VLF transmitters, equatorial ion cyclotron emissions, ion Bernstein mode emissions, and electric field turbulence along the auroral field lines. These files contain 8 second resolution emphemeris and spacecraft attitude parameters that coincide with DE-1 telemetry frames containing PWI lowrate data. These parameters are not to be taken as an authoritative set, but are convenient when working with PWI science data products. Most of these data are provided in the Geocentric Equatorial Inertial (GEI) TOD reference frame. The Z axis of the GEI frame is parallel to Earth's spin axis; the X axis points towards the First Point of Aries with the Y axis aligned so as to generate a right-handed coordinate system.
ResourceHeader.Acknowledgement: Users of the DE-1 PWI data are encouraged to acknowledge NASA CDAWeb and The University of Iowa as the source of the data in any publication.

AccessInformation.Acknowledgement: Users of the DE-1 PWI data are encouraged to acknowledge NASA CDAWeb and The University of Iowa as the source of the data in any publication.

Parameter.Name: Epoch
Parameter.Description: NSSDC standard reference time associated with the start of a PWI SFR sweep

Parameter.Name: GEI Velocity
Parameter.Description: GEI (Geocentric Equatorial Inertial) Satellite Velocity Vector (km/sec). The order of the vector components is v(x), v(y), v(z).

Parameter.Name: Altitude
Parameter.Description: Altitude above a spheroid Earth, not above the geoid.

Parameter.Name: Geographic Latitude
Parameter.Description: Geographic latitude of subsatellite point in degrees

Parameter.Name: Geographic Longitude
Parameter.Description: Geographic longitude of the satellite in degrees

Parameter.Name: MLT
Parameter.Description: Magnetic Local Time. MLT was defined via the conventional Solar Magnetic frame.

Parameter.Name: Invariant Latitude
Parameter.Description: Current spacecraft field line footprint's geomagnetic latitude.

Parameter.Name: B Magnitude
Parameter.Description: Magnetic field strength. Any discrepancy between these data and those provided by the magnetometer instrument's own files should be resolved in favor of the latter. See 'Magnetic Field Observations on DE-A and -B', W. H. Farthing, et al., Space Science Instrumentation 5 (1981) for more information.

Parameter.Name: B Vector (GEI)
Parameter.Description: GEI (Geocentric Equatorial Inertial) Magnetic Vector in nanoTesla. The order of the vector components is B(x), B(y), B(z). Any discrepancy between these data and those provided by the magnetometer instrument's own files should be resolved in favor of the latter. See 'Magnetic Field Observations on DE-A and -B', W. H. Farthing, et al., Space Science Instrumentation 5 (1981) for more information.

Parameter.Name: Orbit Number
Parameter.Description: The orbit number from PWI archive files.

Parameter.Name: GEI Rotation
Parameter.Description: 3-by-3 rotation matrix for the transformation from spacecraft coordinates to the GEI frame. The order of the elements is [1,1] = X(x), [1,2] = X(y), [1,3] = X(z), [2,1] = Y(x), [2,2] = Y(y), [2,3] = Y(z), [3,1] = Z(x), [3,2] = Z(y), and [3,3] = Z(z)

Parameter.Name: GEI Position
Parameter.Description: Spacecraft position in GEI coordinates, the order of the coordinates is X, Y, Z.

Parameter.Name: GEI Relative Velocity
Parameter.Description: GEI (Geocentric Equatorial Inertial) Satellite Velocity Vector (km/sec) relative to a rotating atmosphere.

Parameter.Name: GEI Sun Position
Parameter.Description: GEI (Geocentric Equatorial Inertial) unit vector toward the sun. The order of the components is X, Y, Z.

Parameter.Name: Spin Phase Angle
Parameter.Description: Angle between the Velocity Vector and the Spacecraft X-axis

Parameter.Name: Re
Parameter.Description: Geocentric radial distance in Earth Radii. Here 1 Re = 6378.2 km
